awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Waste Torrefaction Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project is to address sustainability by conversing waste into a clean and renewable resource. Waste incineration has been practiced for some time and brings operational difficulties and high emissions. The proposed project advances a technology to convert waste into a a solid fuel. 

The proposed project advances a torrefaction solution for industrial use. Torrefied waste is significantly low in hazardous components (chlorine) and can be pulverized, enabling application as a solid renewable fuel.  However, waste is a feedstock that is extremely difficult to handle and convey due to low density and large inconsistencies.  The chlorine content of waste can (i) cause severe corrosion and (ii) require strict emission control, with significant increase in cost. Further, it cannot be used in pulverized fuel boilers as it is not grindable. This project advances a small torrefaction system (50 kg/hr) addressing these issues by developing: (1) a waste handling unit that downsizes to 2 mm size with a unique feeding system that avoids bridging; (2) a cramming unit that can handle hard to flow and low-density materials; and (3) a cooling system for safety; and (4) a torrefaction-extrusion reactor. This reactor does the following: (i) reduces the organic chlorine to acceptable levels; (ii) decomposes long polymeric chains and makes the material friable, thus grindable; (iii) homogenizes and downsizing the material due to mechanical mixing; and (iv) uses an integrated compaction that reduces footprint and improves the economics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Introduction:

The key idea behind the technology used in this project is to use non-recyclable materials to produce power. The plastics from bottles and milk containers can be mostly recycled, however, most of other plastics like multilayer packaging films almost always end up in landfills. While paper and similar fiber-based products are biodegradable, they decompose in landfills to create methane and similar greenhouse gases. Thus, the idea is to combine paper and plastic to form stable feedstocks that can substitute for coal and reduce landfill mass to produce greener energy. Nevertheless, there are multiple challenges to overcome, such as the need to produce consistent feedstock, the need to ensure fuel produced is economical compared to other solid fuels, moisture -resistance, and that it does not catch on fire by itself during storage.

Team at ZiTechnologies in collaboration with Michigan Technological University developed and built this technology for combining non-recyclable plastics and paper fiber that would otherwise end up in landfills to form pellets with an energy content like bituminous coal. The key process used is called torrefaction. It is a thermal process to convert feedstock into a coal-like material. It uses mild temperatures, typically between 200°C and 425°C, in an oxygen-free environment to make feedstock more friable, homogenized, water-resistant, and consistent while also removing chlorine and other compounds that can turn into harmful gases during combustion. Pellets produced from this feedstock are 1/4-1/2 inch in diameter and are of uniform geometry and composition and with reduced emissions, and contaminants such as chlorine.

Project Goals:

To demonstrate the feasibility of the process, the goal of this project was to produce pellets in a pilot scale unit and generate the understanding and know-how required for the commercialization of this technology. Additionally, to confirm the reduced emissions and the economic viability of the technology, Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) and Techno-Economic Assessment (TEA), respectively were to be performed. Further, technology and product safety challenges were discovered and needed to be addressed.

Outcomes:  

During the span of the project, the samples of the fiber-plastic waste blend (40% plastic and 60% fiber) derived from a large variety of paper, laminated papers, plastics, and fibers were sourced from various sources. Our industrial partner removed ferrous and non-ferrous metals. The material was then shredded to the appropriate particle size and aspect ratio and then dried to a 5-7% moisture content level. The material was then processed in the torrefaction pilot unit at Michigan Tech. The tests aimed to reduce the amount of chlorine and produce materials similar to bituminous coal. Production of up to 10-tons of material was planned to gain extensive operational experience. In parallel, the basic engineering for the next stage was planned.

LCA/TEA study outcome: The LCA study showed a reduction of greenhouse gasses from the switch to torrefied plastic-fiber pellets will be 87% (for coal) and 84% (for natural gas). While TEA results showed the fuel can be produced at $2.21/MMBTU, competing with current coal and natural gas prices.

Basic engineering work: This work for scale-up of the technology was successfully completed showing the availability of sufficient energy to process materials to self-sustain the process for feedstock with up to 40% moisture content.

Pellet and equipment safety: Key issues were discovered during the project and additional efforts were put in to successfully address them. Water cooling was found to be the optimal cooling mechanism instead of previously deployed air cooling. It was found that no water penetrates the pellets and only accumulates on the surface. This water also easily evaporated when stored outside in ambient conditions.

Operation of the torrefaction pilot system: Hundreds of hours of operational experience was gained as part of this project which provided valuable learnings required for further commercialization work.

Conclusion and Next Steps:

We have successfully demonstrated the viability of the Waste Torrefaction Technology for commercialization. Currently, ZiTechnologies is starting the work on the scale-up system to demonstrate the technical and economic viability of the technology at scale. The place for the installation of the commercial demonstration unit was selected and funding sources were identified. The engineering work will start in Q2 of 2023. The commercial demonstration unit in its first industrial stage will be able to produce up to 25,000 tons/year of torrefied pellets. Those pellets will be used as renewable, support baseload energy plants, and provide a much-needed source of energy in the State of Wisconsin. Later, the additional similar unit can be added to increase the production capacity of the torrefaction facility.
